headline.main: THE PANAMA RAILROAD.; Interesting Report of the Excursion. SCENES ON THE ROUTE. THE BANQUET. Speeches, Toasts, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Previous letters have informed you of the safe arrival of our party at Aspinwall on the morning of the 16th inst. We were immediately taken in charge by Col. TOTTEN and Mr. CENTER; and after enjoying for a few hours the quiet and rest which travelers only can appreciate, we proceeded to examine the workshops of the Company, which we found admirably located and well arranged; and afterwards: wandered about the place.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The men of Jersey are in great commotion at the wickedness of the proposition now before our Legislature to adorn one of their sandy necks of land with beautiful hospitals. Correspondents from that owe-nothing and tax-gathering State assure us that the Quarantine buildings cannot be located on their territory on any considerations.

headline.main: FROM WASHINGTON.; The Collins Triumph--Matters in Congress. Senator Sumner on the Collins Line.

docs.lead_paragraph: The battle is over, and Congress has sustained the Collins' Line. These are simple words, but they will inspire emotions of joy and pride in the hearts of our people all over the land. It is sourcely necessary to give here any details of the fight in the Senate,--for of these the telegraph has already notified you.

byline.original: Special Correspondence of the N. Y. Daily Times

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; DEATH OF JUDGE EDWARDS. Speeches of Charles O'Conor, Judges Roosvelt, Oakley and Rosworth, John McKeon and others. BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH OF JUDGE EDWARDS. Departure of John Mitchel. Lecture of William Lloyd Garrison. City Railroads--Reduction of Fare. Mayor's Compliant Book. MARKET BANK EMBEZZLEMENT. Adjourned Examination of W. P. Sackett. COURT CALENDAR--THURSDAY,

docs.lead_paragraph: Business in the Courts of the City was entirely suspended yesterday, in respect to the memory of the late Judge EDWARDS, of the Supreme Court, whose decease was briefly announced in-the DAILY TIMES of yesterday. / HENRY PIERREPONT EDWARDS was born in New-Haven in the year 1808; consequently-he was forty-seven years of age. e was the second

headline.main: PAUPERISM.; The Cause and a Remedy.--A Letter from Jane G. Swisshelm.

docs.lead_paragraph: Any one who will observe, must see that the poor are crowded into cities, which they are very unwilling to leave-that our lands are uncultivated wastes, while the hands that should make them blossom as the rose, are learning the arts of pauperism and crime in unwholesome dens and caves of the earth; in dirty alleys, where sun-light, pure air and green grass are supplied in homeopathic quantities, or totally forbidden. There must
